bioghist.p: Samuel Frederic Houston (1866-1952) and Charlotte Harding Shepherd (1867-1940) were married in Philadelphia in 1902. The marriage was the second for both Sam and Charlotte. Sam's first marriage, in 1887, to Edith Atlee Corlies (1864-1895) of Philadelphia, resulted in three children, Edith (1888-1970), Margaret (1891-1970), and Henry Howard II (1895-1918). Edith died from complications developed after the birth of Henry, in 1895. Henry II died while a soldier in World War I. After about seven years of living at Druim Moir with his children and mother, Sallie Sherrerd Bonnell Houston, Sam married Charlotte. Charlotte, a widow and friend of Sam's first wife, brought two children to Druim Moir, Charles Wardell Brown, Jr. (1891-1951) and Charlotte Harding Brown (1895-1973). Sam and Charlotte had one child together, Eleanor, born in the summer of 1910. The Houstons took a number of trips abroad, chief amongst was a 1902-1903 trip to Europe. Sam, Charlotte and the children sailed the eastern Mediterranean and made ports of call at Tunis, Malta, Zante, Delphi, Corinth, Athens, Constantinople, Knossos, Gournia, and Venice.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Samuel Frederic Houston and his wife Charlotte. Materials include; correspondence; clippings; invitation acceptance lists; scrapbooks; photographs documenting the familyâ€™s several trips to Europe; and a notebook entitled "Books We Have Read" in which Sam and Charlotte list books read, by author, with a short review of each. The collection also includes correspondence, clippings, invitations, photographs, printed material, a scrapbook, and postcards regarding Henry's military service in France, and his death there in the summer of 1918.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
